abstract.text: Processes a Live Photo with your edits for viewing.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The size of the view in which you plan to preview the edited Live Photo output.
Options that affect Live Photo rendering. See
A block that Photos calls on the main queue after processing is complete. The block takes the following parameters:
The rendered Live Photo, suitable for displaying in a
object.
livePhoto
If preparing the edited Live Photo for display succeeds, this parameter is
. If processing fails, the
parameter is
, and this parameter contains an error object describing the failure.
error
Use this method to generate preview versions of the edited Live Photo—for example, to display in your editing UI.
This method does not guarantee performance appropriate for interactive editing. Instead, you might preview edits interactively using a still image (see the
property), and use this method to produce animated reviews upon the user’s request.

abstract.text: Work with image and video assets that the Photos app manages, including those from iCloud Photos and Live Photos.
A displayable representation of a Live Photo—a picture that includes motion and sound from the moments just before and after its capture.
An editing session for modifying the photo, video, and audio content of a Live Photo.
Aborts any Live Photo processing in progress.
The unedited still photo content of the Live Photo.
Processes a Live Photo with your edits for viewing.
Processes and saves a full-quality Live Photo as the output of your editing session.
dictionary used with the methods listed in Processing an Editing Context’s Live Photo.
A view that displays a Live Photo—a picture that also includes motion and sound from the moments just before and after its capture.
A structure that contains width and height values.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
A Unicode string value that is a collection of characters.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
